Potential Impact of the Technology Solution:

Signal180 will significantly improve network reliability and reduce downtime for telecom providers. By predicting outages before they occur and automating response workflows:

  1. Communities stay connected during emergencies, natural disasters, and daily communication needs.
  2. Customer satisfaction increases as service interruptions are minimized.
  3. Operational costs are reduced through smarter maintenance and optimized technician deployment.
  4. Data-driven decisions enable telecom companies to plan infrastructure upgrades proactively.
  5. Supports digital inclusion, ensuring rural or underserved areas maintain access to critical services such as online education, telehealth, and emergency communication.
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Telecom providers struggle with unreliable network coverage and delayed outage detection, causing customer dissatisfaction, revenue loss, and high maintenance costs. Traditional monitoring tools only react after customers complain there is no proactive system to predict outages or automatically alert engineers before service degradation occurs. The challenge is to create an intelligent, real time platform that monitors network health, predicts potential outages, and triggers automated response workflows to restore service faster.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

How I Envision the Ideal Solution

The ideal solution is a real-time, AI-powered network health and outage management system that automatically monitors telecom infrastructure, predicts potential outages, and triggers fast, automated responses.

Key Features:

  • Predictive Alerts: AI analyzes historical and real time tower data to forecast outages before they occur.
  • Automated Incident Creation: Flow Designer automatically creates incidents for engineers when a tower or router shows critical signal degradation.
  • Dynamic Dashboards: Performance Analytics visualizes network health, regional coverage, and outage trends in real time.
  • Virtual Agent Notifications: Customers and technicians receive proactive notifications about outages or maintenance tasks.
  • CMDB Driven Infrastructure Mapping: All towers, routers, and regions are mapped in CMDB to show relationships and impact zones.

 

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Technical Dependencies for Signal180

  1. ServiceNow Developer Instance (PDI)

The project requires a personal developer instance to build the app, configure CMDB, Flow Designer, Performance Analytics, and Virtual Agent.

  1. CMDB Data Structure

Towers, routers, and regions must be modeled correctly in CMDB with proper relationships to support impact analysis and automated workflows.

  1. Event Data Input

Network signal strength and device status data must be available, can use:

Mock data (CSV/JSON) for hackathon/demo

API integration from telecom monitoring tools (optional for real-world deployment)

  1. Predictive Intelligence Model

Requires historical or simulated network outage data to train AI to predict outages accurately.

  1. Flow Designer & Automation Rules

Automated incident creation, notifications, and workflow execution rely on proper Flow Designer configuration.

  1. Performance Analytics Dashboard Setup

KPIs, metrics, and visualization widgets must be created to display network health, outage trends, and SLA compliance.

  1. Optional Integrations

Virtual Agent for notifications

Mapping APIs for visualizing tower locations

 

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Challenges in Implementing Signal180

  1. Data Accuracy & Availability

Real time tower and router data may not always be available or accurate.

For the hackathon, this is solved with simulated data, but in real deployment, you’d need reliable integration with telecom monitoring systems.

  1. CMDB Complexity

Modeling hundreds or thousands of network devices with proper relationships can be complex.

Incorrect dependencies could lead to misidentified outage impacts.

  1. Predictive Intelligence Training

AI predictions require sufficient historical data to be accurate.

Insufficient or noisy data could cause false positives/negatives in outage predictions.

  1. Integration with External Systems

Real telecom systems (IoT sensors, APIs, or monitoring tools) may require secure integration and credentials.

Any API failures or latency could affect automated incident creation.

  1. Scalability

Handling large numbers of devices and real-time events can be challenging.

Performance analytics dashboards and automation flows must be optimized for speed.

  1. User Adoption & Alert Fatigue

If too many alerts are sent, engineers or customers may ignore notifications.

Flows must prioritize critical incidents and avoid spam.
